note: I. Israel, The Dutch Republic (Oxford University Press, ). The Baltic area is competently surveyed in D. Kirby, Northern Europe in the Early-Modern Period: the Baltic World (London, ). The most convenient English-language study of the development of Brandenburg-Prussia is still F. Schevill, The Great Elector (New York, ). The beginnings of the future Austrian Empire are studied in R. J. W. Evans, The Making of the Habsburg Monarchy, – (Oxford, ). Finally eastern Europe can be covered through N. Davies, God’s Playground: a History of Poland,

title: Politics A reliable and up-to-date general account of the period is found in T. Munck, Seventeenth-century Europe, – (London, ), and a comprehensive survey of the key political players of the age in H

The following works, chosen from a range of possibilities will give an introduction to developments in the individual countries of Europe in this period. France is covered in R. Bonney, Political Change in France under Richelieu and Mazarin
A stimulating comparison of French and Spanish experience can be found
and a reliable survey of Spain in the seventeenth century in John Lynch, Spain under the Habsburgs

Those of the end of the century are chronicled from different perspectives in

The Sinews of Power. War, Money and the English State, – (London, ) is an authoritative analysis of how one state became a ‘military-fiscal’ power. Diplomacy and power politics are the subject of R
Espions et ambassadeurs au temps de Louis XIV
The continuing dynasticism of most European states and its impact on their conduct can be gleaned from P

container-title: The Contest of Cultures in Colonial North America (New York and Oxford
note: Some of the themes of the present essay are also to be found in James Tully, An Approach to Political Philosophy: Locke in Contexts (Cambridge, ) and Anthony Pagden, Lords of All The World. Ideologies of Empire in Spain, Britain and France, c.–c. (New Haven and London, ).
title: Europe and the non-European world The background to European expansion is amply covered in G

The Old World and the New – (Cambridge, ) is a classic brief survey which embraces cultural as well as other forms of interaction. A more recent approach to the same topic is exemplified in James Axtell, The Invasion Within

The Trading World of Asia and the English East-India Company – (Cambridge, ) and Jonathan Israel, The Dutch Republic and the Hispanic World – (Oxford, ) both focus primarily on the commercial rivalries of the European powers, while Robin Blackburn’s, The Making of New-World Slavery (London, ) is a massive and passionate analysis of one of European expansion’s most enduring black spots

container-title: Death of Philip II. King Sigismund of Sweden deposed, replaced by Charles IX. 1600 Time of Troubles in Russia. Creation of English East India Company
note: Giordano Bruno burnt for heresy, Rome.
title: ) traces the long-term evolution of a key political concept. Chronology: The ‘The Long Seventeenth Century’, 1598–1715 1598 Edict of Nantes. Treaty of Vervins, peace between France and Spain
Creation of Dutch East India Company
Union of crowns of England and Scotland under James I. 1604 Peace between England and Spain

publisher: Paul V places Venice under Interdict
title: Settlement of the Hungarian revolt against Emperor Rudolf II
Venetian interdict removed. Monteverdi’s Orfeo first performed

container-title: Emperor’s ‘Letter of Majesty’ to Bohemian Protestants. Rival confessional alliances formed in Empire (–). Expulsion of Moriscos from Spain. Kepler, Astronomia nova
title: Twelve Years’ Truce between the Spanish and the Dutch Republic

author.literal: Assassination of Henri IV of France

title: Marie de Medici regent for underage Louis XIII. Polish garrison driven out of Moscow

author.literal: Death of Rudolf II, election of Matthias as Holy Roman Emperor.

title: Treaty of Xanten settles disputed claims over Cleves-Jülich
Michael Romanov elected Tsar by Assembly of the Land
Aristocratic revolt followed by convocation of last French Estates General before
François de Sales, Treatise on the love of God
Ferdinand of Styria recognized as designated Habsburg successor to kingdoms of Bohemia and Hungary. Louis XIII seizes control of government from Marie de Medicis and her favourite, Concini
Defenestration of Prague, beginning of Bohemian revolt. Dutch synod of Dort, victory of strict Calvinists (Gomarists) over Arminians
Austrian and allied forces crush Bohemians at White Mountain. Spanish occupy and garrison the Valtelline. Resumption of Huguenot wars in France. Pilgrim Fathers found Plymouth, Massachusetts
Philip IV king of Spain. War in the Netherlands resumed

publisher: Philip Neri, Francis Xavier, Teresa of Avila
title: Olivares become valido of Philip IV. chronology | 235 Canonization of Ignatius Loyola
Palatine Electorate transferred to Duke Maximilian of Bavaria
Richelieu enters royal council and replaces leading minister, La Vieuville. Spanish begin successful siege of Breda

note: Christian IV of Denmark defeated at Lutter.
title: Huguenot revolt in France. Peace settlement with Spain at Monzon, leaving Valtelline under Spanish control
Death of duke Vincenzo II, Gonzaga of Mantua, opens succession struggle

container-title: Petition of Right in England
title: First Spanish siege of Casale-Monferrato. Habsburgs impose settlement on Bohemia. Fall of La Rochelle after year-long siege

container-title: First issue of French Gazette
title: Peace of Cherasco ending Franco-Spanish war in north Italy. Swedish victory at Breitenfeld. Franco-Swedish treaty of Bärwald

container-title: Dutch capture Maastricht
title: Wallenstein checks Swedish army. Death of Gustavus Adolphus at Lützen
Swedish-led League of Heilbronn formed, subsidized by France. France invades duchy of Lorraine. Galileo’s views condemned by Urban VIII as heretical
Form of Government’ in Sweden
Peace of Prague. France declares war on Spain. Letters patent granted to French Academy
1636 Spanish and Austrian armies invade France

container-title: Galileo, New Science. chronology
title: Covenanter revolt against Charles I in Scotland

publisher: Posthumous publication of Cornelius Jansen’s Augustinus
title: Revolts of Catalonia and Portugal versus Castilian monarchy. Short and Long Parliaments in England. Frederick-William succeeds as Elector of Brandenburg

container-title: Revolt in Ireland
title: Grand remonstrance in England
Death of Richelieu. Civil war in Britain

author.literal: French victory over Spaniards at Rocroi. Death of Louis XIII, his son Louis XIV a minor.

container-title: Disgrace of Olivares
title: Anne of Austria regent, Cardinal Mazarin chief minister

container-title: Formation of New Model Army in England
title: Peace conferences assemble in Westphalia. Descartes, Principia philosophiae. 1645 Battle of Jankow. Treaty of Brömsebro between Sweden and Denmark
English parliament wins first civil war
Anti-Spanish revolt in Naples and Palermo

author.literal: Execution of Charles I. Republic declared.

title: Ulozhenie (law code) voted by Assembly recognizes the autocracy and tightens serfdom in Russia. Beginning of noble Fronde
Failure of William II’s coup in Holland

container-title: English Navigation Act voted. Hobbes’s Leviathan published
title: 1651 Louis XIV comes of age, noble revolt continues

container-title: End of Ukrainian peasants’ revolt. First use of liberum veto in Polish Diet
title: Castilian reconquest of Barcelona. First Anglo-Dutch War
Anglo-Dutch peace treaty
French defeat at Valenciennes. Sweden attacks Poland-Lithuania

publisher: Publication of Pascal’s Provincial Letters. chronology |
title: Denmark attacks Sweden, and Swedish troops overrun Jutland
Peace of the Pyrennes

author.literal: Restoration of Charles II in England.

container-title: Regency government in Sweden for Charles XI
title: Treaty of Oliva between Sweden, Brandenburg and Poland. Frederick William of Brandenburg takes control of East Prussia

note: Declaration of hereditary monarchy in Denmark.
title: Death of Mazarin, beginning of the personal rule of Louis XIV. Start of major army reforms of Michel Le Tellier and Louvoi

author.literal: Carlos II king of Spain. Second Anglo-Dutch War.

title: Royal Danish law codifying absolute monarchy
War of Devolution in the Spanish Netherlands
The Adventures of Simplicius Simplicissimus

note: Spinoza, Tractatus theologico-politicus. 240 | the seventeenth century
title: Hungarian revolt against Habsburgs. First edition of Pascal’s Pensées
Malebranche, Recherches de la vérité
Defeat of Swedes by Prussians at Fehrbellin
Opening of popish plot and exclusion crisis in Britain
Sweden’s Estates formally recognize royal absolutism, authorize resumption of crown lands

container-title: Revolt of Hungarian magnates against Habsburgs
title: French take Strasbourg as part of the policy of réunions
Ottoman siege of Vienna, defeated at battle of Kahlenberg. End of exclusion crisis in Britain
Pierre Bayle begins publishing Nouvelles de la République des Lettres

container-title: Death of Charles II of England, succession of James II
title: Revocation of the Edict of Nantes
Formation of League of Augsburg in the Empire to resist French aggression. Buda recaptured from Ottomans
Habsburgs and Hungarian nobility reach compromise at Diet of Pressburg
France intervenes in dispute over Archbishopric of Cologne

note: Tsar Peter I (‘the Great’) seizes power in Russia.
title: First campaign of Nine Years War

author.literal: William of Orange defeats James II and Irish supporters.

note: Anglo-French naval battle of Bézeviers (Beachy Head).
title: John Locke’s An Essay Concerning Human Understanding and Two Treatises on Government
Battle of Steenkirk
Bank of England created

container-title: Treaty of Ryswick ends the Nine Years War. Pierre Bayle, Historical and critical dictionary. Consecration of St. Paul’s Cathedral
title: Augustus Elector of Saxony is elected King of Poland. Austrian army commanded by Prince Eugene defeats the Turks at Zenta; reconquest of Hungary completed
Second Partition Treaty (of Spanish succession) between Louis XIV

container-title: Russia replaces Byzantine calendar with Julian
title: Death of Joseph Ferdinand, son of the Bavarian Elector and heirdesignate by the Partition Treaty to the Spanish inheritance. Peace of Karlowitz ends war between Austria and the Turks. Fénélon’s Aventures de Télémaque published

publisher: Great Northern War against Sweden begins
title: Death of Carlos II, who willed Spanish inheritance to Louis’ grandson, the future Philip V of Spain. Louis XIV accepts Spanish legacy
Peter the Great founds St Petersburg. Rakoczy revolt versus Habsburgs in Hungary
First national daily newspaper founded in England
Siege of Barcelona. Death of Emperor Leopold, succeeded by Joseph I
Battle of Ramillies and relief of Turin
Union of England and Scotland
Battle of Oudenarde, siege of Lille. Vauban publishes Project d’une dixme royale
Breakdown of peace negotations between Bourbons and Allies. Meissen porcelain manufactory established in Saxony
Resumption of Anglo-French peace talks. Emperor Joseph I dies, succeeded by Charles VI. Compromise between Habsburgs and Hungarians at Szathmar. Spectator appears for first time
Treaties of Utrecht (to ), followed in  by Treaties of Rastatt and Baden. George Elector of Hanover becomes George I. Papal bull Unigenitus condemns  propositions tainted by Jansenism
Death of Louis XIV
